title: 2D Shapes and Their Properties
description: Identify and describe the properties of common two-dimensional shapes
objectives: Name common 2D shapes: circle, triangle, square, rectangle, pentagon, hexagon
Describe shapes using sides and corners (vertices)

sections.title: Shapes All Around Us!
sections.content:
Look around you right now. Can you spot a rectangle? How about a circle? Shapes are everywhere -- in windows, wheels, signs and even slices of pizza!

**Two-dimensional (2D) shapes** are flat shapes. They have **length** and **width** but no thickness (you can draw them on paper). Let's learn to name and describe them!

sections.title: Common 2D Shapes
sections.content:
Every 2D shape has **sides** (straight edges) and **corners** (also called **vertices**, where sides meet).

| Shape | Sides | Corners | Special features |
|-------|-------|---------|------------------|
| Circle | 0 (curved) | 0 | Perfectly round |
| Triangle | 3 | 3 | Tri = three |
| Square | 4 | 4 | All sides equal, all corners square |
| Rectangle | 4 | 4 | Opposite sides equal, all corners square |
| Pentagon | 5 | 5 | Penta = five |
| Hexagon | 6 | 6 | Hexa = six |

A **square** is actually a special type of rectangle -- one where all four sides are the same length!

The **circle** is special because it has no straight sides and no corners. It's perfectly round.

sections.title: Example: Describing a Shape
sections.content: I am a shape with 4 sides. Two of my sides are long and two are short. All my corners are square corners. What shape am I?
steps: The shape has 4 sides -- so it could be a square or rectangle
Two sides are long and two are short -- the sides are not all equal
All corners are square (right angles)
This must be a **rectangle** (not a square, because the sides aren't all the same length)

sections.title: Sides and Corners Are Connected
sections.content:
Here's an amazing pattern: for shapes with straight sides, the **number of sides always equals the number of corners**!

- Triangle: 3 sides, 3 corners
- Square: 4 sides, 4 corners
- Pentagon: 5 sides, 5 corners
- Hexagon: 6 sides, 6 corners

This makes sense because each corner is made where two sides meet.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Fantastic! In this lesson you learned:

- **2D shapes** are flat shapes you can draw on paper
- Shapes have **sides** (edges) and **corners** (vertices)
- Key shapes: circle, triangle, square, rectangle, pentagon, hexagon
- The number of **sides = the number of corners** for straight-sided shapes

Go on a shape hunt! How many different shapes can you find in your classroom?

workedExamples.title: Identifying a Shape from a Description
workedExamples.problem: I have 6 sides and 6 corners. What shape am I?
steps: Count the sides: 6
A shape with 6 sides is called a hexagon (hexa = six)
Check: a hexagon has 6 corners ✓
workedExamples.explanation: The prefix 'hexa' means six. A hexagon has 6 straight sides and 6 corners.

workedExamples.title: Sorting Shapes by Properties
workedExamples.problem: Sort these shapes into two groups -- those with 4 sides and those without: triangle, square, pentagon, rectangle, hexagon.
steps: Triangle: 3 sides -- NOT 4 sides
Square: 4 sides -- YES
Pentagon: 5 sides -- NOT 4 sides
Rectangle: 4 sides -- YES
Hexagon: 6 sides -- NOT 4 sides
workedExamples.solution: **4 sides:** square, rectangle. **Not 4 sides:** triangle, pentagon, hexagon.
workedExamples.explanation: Shapes with exactly 4 sides are called quadrilaterals. Both squares and rectangles are quadrilaterals.

title: Symmetry and Giving Directions
description: Explore lines of symmetry and give simple directions using positional language
objectives: Identify lines of symmetry in shapes and pictures
Use positional language: left, right, forward, backward, between, next to

sections.title: Mirror, Mirror and Finding Your Way!
sections.content:
Have you ever folded a piece of paper in half and noticed both sides look the same? That's **symmetry**!

In this lesson, we'll also learn how to describe where things are and give directions. These skills help us read maps and find our way around.

sections.title: Lines of Symmetry
sections.content:
A **line of symmetry** divides a shape into two halves that are **mirror images** of each other. If you folded along the line, both halves would match up perfectly.

**Examples of symmetry:**
- A **square** has 4 lines of symmetry (horizontal, vertical and two diagonals)
- A **rectangle** has 2 lines of symmetry (horizontal and vertical)
- A **circle** has infinite lines of symmetry (any line through the centre)
- An **equilateral triangle** has 3 lines of symmetry

**Testing for symmetry:** Imagine folding the shape along the line. If both sides would match up perfectly, it's a line of symmetry. If not, it isn't!

Some shapes (like the letter F) have **no lines of symmetry** at all.

sections.title: Giving and Following Directions
sections.content:
We use special words to describe **where things are** and **how to get somewhere**:

**Position words:**
- **Left** and **right**
- **Above** and **below**
- **Next to** and **between**
- **In front of** and **behind**

**Direction words:**
- **Forward** (go straight ahead)
- **Backward** (go behind you)
- **Turn left** and **turn right**

**Example:** "Walk forward 3 steps, then turn right and walk forward 2 steps."

When giving directions, be clear and use **exact numbers** so the person knows exactly what to do.

sections.title: Example: Finding Lines of Symmetry
sections.content: How many lines of symmetry does a rectangle have?
steps: Try a vertical line down the middle -- left half matches right half ✓
Try a horizontal line across the middle -- top half matches bottom half ✓
Try a diagonal line -- the halves do NOT match ✗
A rectangle has **2 lines of symmetry**

sections.title: Symmetry in Everyday Life
sections.content:
Symmetry is everywhere in the real world:

- **Nature**: butterflies, leaves, snowflakes
- **Letters**: A, B, C, D, H, M, O, T, U, V, W, X, Y all have at least one line of symmetry
- **Buildings**: many buildings are symmetrical from the front
- **Your body**: your left side roughly mirrors your right side!

Artists, architects and designers use symmetry to make things look balanced and beautiful.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Wonderful work! In this lesson you learned:

- A **line of symmetry** divides a shape into two matching halves
- Different shapes have different numbers of lines of symmetry
- **Position words** describe where things are (left, right, above, below)
- **Direction words** help us navigate (forward, turn left, turn right)

Try folding paper shapes to find their lines of symmetry!

workedExamples.title: Counting Lines of Symmetry
workedExamples.problem: How many lines of symmetry does an equilateral triangle (all sides equal) have?
steps: Try a line from the top corner to the middle of the bottom side -- halves match ✓
Try a line from the bottom-left corner to the middle of the opposite side -- halves match ✓
Try a line from the bottom-right corner to the middle of the opposite side -- halves match ✓
No other lines work
workedExamples.solution: An equilateral triangle has **3 lines of symmetry**.
workedExamples.explanation: Each line of symmetry goes from one corner to the midpoint of the opposite side. Since there are 3 corners, there are 3 lines.

workedExamples.title: Following Directions
workedExamples.problem: Start at the school gate. Walk forward 4 steps. Turn right. Walk forward 2 steps. Where might you be?
steps: Start at the school gate, facing forward
Walk forward 4 steps (you've moved ahead)
Turn right (you're now facing a new direction)
Walk forward 2 steps
You might be at the library, playground or another place to the right of the path
workedExamples.solution: You are **4 steps ahead and 2 steps to the right** of the school gate.
workedExamples.explanation: Following directions step by step helps us reach the right place. Each instruction must be done in order.
